DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Gain On Talk Of Chinese Demand
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices rose modestly Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid rumors that China was seeking to buy 410,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat. Corn closed mixed and soybean futures finished lower. The talk of Chinese interest in wheat was rooted in active buying of wheat futures by commercial grain dealers known to do business with China. The corn and soybean markets drifted mostly lower on light-volume trading characteristic of pre-holiday sessions. ``It was a very quiet, dull session,'' said Victor Lespinasse, a floor trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. All contracts for December deliveries expired at noon. December wheat went off the board 4 cents lower at $4.11 a bushel, December corn was 1 cent lower at $2.33{ a bushel and December oats were 2 cents lower at $1.40 a bushel. There was no December soybean contract. At the close, wheat was } cent to 2{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.14{ a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to 1 cent higher with March at $2.38{ a bushel; oats were \ cent to } cent higher with March at $1.52{ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 2{ cents lower with January at $5.78\ a bushel.
